awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Atomic-Scale Visualization of Excitonic States in Individual Carbon Nanotubes
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Professor George Nazin of the University of Oregon will develop new measurement techniques for the visualization of the energy states of individual carbon nanotubes.  Carbon nanotubes, or "CNTs" are a form of the element Carbon which have current applications in composite materials, but also have potential for interesting applications in electronics, optoelectronics and bioimaging.  Professor Nazin is investigating the electronic and photophysical properties of CNTs. The Nazin group is employing a spatially-resolved spectroscopic technique that allows the team to obtain real-space atomic-resolution electronic maps of individual pristine and chemically-modified CNTs. This work aims to develop a detailed picture of CNT photophysics, which will help guide the principles for rational design of applications based on CNTs. 

The goal of the project is to establish a quantitative microscopic model of CNT photophysics through direct measurements of spectral structures and spatial behaviors of electronic states corresponding to electronic excitations (excitons) in CNTs. These studies are enabled by a novel scanning tunneling microscope constructed recently by the Nazin group. In this experimental approach, tunneling electrons are used as the excitation source, which allows investigations of CNT photophysics with atomic-scale spatial resolution, currently inaccessible to any other experimental technique. In addition to the direct characterization of excitonic states, spatially-resolved measurements of individual CNTs provide insights into the fundamentally important processes of exciton transport and quenching, the role of defects in these processes, and chemical approaches to controlling these processes. The project is integrated with a middle/high school outreach program developed by Professor Nazin in collaboration with the Springfield, Oregon, school district. The program, designed with teacher input in order to fulfill state science standards, provides year-round engagement of students through hands-on science activities held at the University of Oregon campus.

por.por_cntn:
Until recently, the ability to visualize the internal workings of electronic processes in molecular-scale systems remained an elusive goal.  This is a direct consequence of the fact that studies of such phenomena traditionally rely on photo-excitation, which is typically spread out over a spatial volume that is orders of magnitude larger than the spatial dimensions of individual molecular systems.   This limitation hinders the development and optimization of a wide range of molecular-scale materials, whose electronic properties can be strongly affected by uncontrolled atomic-scale variations in the chemical structure, the presence of individual defects, and subtle environmental variations.   These challenges highlight the need for a characterization technique capable of probing the electronic processes in such materials with atomic-scale resolution.  

 

The objective of this project was to establish a relationship between the local environment, chemical structure and properties of electronic states in molecular-scale systems. Our experimental approach is based on the direct visualization of the spatial behavior of electronic states by using Scanning Tunneling Microscopy, where highly-spatially confined tunneling of electrons enables atomic-scale spatial resolution. In the course of the project, we have investigated a number of technologically important molecular-scale materials, including carbon nanotubes, lead-sulfide and silicon nanocrystals, as well as organic semiconductor molecules. Importantly, these investigations were carried out in atomically well-defined environments involving metallic and atomically-thin insulating surfaces. Our results demonstrate significant environment-induced structural and electronic variations in these materials, as well as the presence of defect-induced electronic states. The presence of these structural and electronic effects can be expected to have dramatic consequences for a wide variety of applications involving these novel materials. Our results quantify these effects, which is essential for the development of such novel technological applications.

 

The project has provided valuable training opportunities for 7 graduate and 11 undergraduate students in the areas of probe microscopy, surface chemistry, solid-state physics, electronics, vacuum technology, optics and cryogenics. These skills are highly valued in industry, with alumni of the project working in a variety of high-tech companies, including companies developing new generations of electronic devices.

 

Support from this grant has enabled our group to further develop our educational/outreach program for middle school and high school students. In this program, students engage in hands-on laboratory activities illustrating a wide range of scientific concepts.
